{{US|reason=partially_misleading|non-US_link=[[Stock asset allocation for non-US investors]] and [[Building a non-US Boglehead portfolio]]}} '''Asset allocation''' means dividing an investment portfolio among different asset classes. Typically these are [[Stock basics|stocks]], [[Bond basics |bonds]], and cash.{{cite web| url=https://www.sec.gov/investor/pubs/assetallocation.htm| title=Beginners' Guide to Asset Allocation, Diversification, and Rebalancing| publisher=SEC| date=August 28, 2009| accessdate=August 9, 2023}} With modifications according to {{forum link| p=2360117| title=Re: Wiki comments requested: The importance of asset allocation}}. Investors use three asset allocation strategies. *'''Strategic asset allocation''' follows the [[Bogleheads® investment philosophy|Bogleheads investment philosophy]]. Strategic asset allocation is designed for the long run. The allocation may change due to life events, but it should not change due to market conditions. *'''Tactical asset allocation'''. [[Tactical asset allocation]] shifts allocations according to economic or valuation factors. Vanguard has historically used [[Tactical asset allocation#Vanguard tactical asset allocation funds|tactical asset allocation]] for a limited number of its balanced funds. *'''Dynamic asset allocation'''. Dynamic asset allocation calls for allocations to shift in accordance with changing future liabilities, a condition especially relevant, since changes in pension law, to institutional defined pension and institutional endowment portfolios, see [https://web.archive.org/web/20160512131137/https://www.dol.gov/ebsa/pensionreform.html The Pension Protection Act Of 2006], Department of Labor, and [https://studylib.net/doc/8651971/glide-path-alm--a-dynamic-allocation-approach-to Glide path ALM: A dynamic allocation approach to derisking]. See [https://web.archive.org/web/20190117023155/https://institutional.vanguard.com/iam/pdf/IAMIPST_122009.pdf Sample investment policy statement XYZ Company Pension Plan], Vanguard, August, 2011 for an example of an IPS employing dynamic asset allocation. Determining which mix of assets to hold in a portfolio is a personal choice. The asset allocation that works best at any given stage in your life will depend largely on your need, ability and willingness take risk. These depend on the investment ''time horizon'', and on your ''financial capacity'' and ''emotional capacity'' to [[Risk tolerance|tolerate risk]] and to [[Bogleheads® investment philosophy#Stay the course|stay the course]]. While this may sound like a daunting task, there are straightforward guidelines to help you choose an appropriate asset allocation. How much in bonds? How much in stocks? That is the basic question of asset allocation. The more risk you can handle, the less bonds you need. When you are young, your prime earning years lie ahead, and it will be decades before you need to access the money. So higher stock allocations may be suitable, because big drops in stock prices will not hurt as long as you do not flee the market. [[John Bogle]] said that "as we age, we usually have (1) more wealth to protect, (2) less time to recoup severe losses, (3) greater need for income, and (4) perhaps an increased nervousness as markets jump around. All four of these factors suggest more bonds as we age."{{cite book| author=John Bogle| author-link=John Bogle| title=Common Sense on Mutual Funds| date=2010| pages=87-88}} Your asset allocation applies to your overall portfolio. You do not need to have the same asset allocation in every account you own; in fact, this may be detrimental. See [[Asset allocation in multiple accounts]] and [[Tax-efficient fund placement]] for more details. ==Strategic asset allocation== A key reason for having an asset allocation strategy is to help you reduce the risks of volatile equity asset classes, ones that are expected to provide higher returns, by combining them with more stable fixed-income assets. These balanced portfolios help reduce volatility and down-side risk, making it easier for you to maintain a long term investment program (stay the course) without panic selling during bear markets. With a '''strategic asset allocation''' - as explained in this article - you choose a base target allocation to a selection of different [[asset class]]es for the long run. Strategic asset allocation is used by investors following the [[Bogleheads® investment philosophy]]. You can change it due to life events, but you should not change it because of market conditions. The main asset classes are equities ([[stock]]), fixed-income ([[bond]]s) and cash. The goal is to select an asset allocation that lets you sleep at night, and ''avoid'' the destructive urge to sell out in a panic the next time the market plummets; then having to agonize over when it is a "good time' to get back in. This leads to selling low and buying high, the exact opposite of prudent investing. Because the three main asset classes - equities, fixed-income, and cash equivalents - have different levels of risk and return, each will behave differently over time. Because of this, you will need to periodically [[Rebalancing|rebalance]] the allocation to these asset classes back to their target allocation to keep the portfolio's risk-return level constant.{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/strategicassetallocation.asp#axzz1mShM43qE| title=Strategic Asset Allocation - Definition of Strategic Asset Allocation on Investopedia| publisher=Investopedia}} A portfolio strategy that involves periodically rebalancing the portfolio in order to maintain a long-term goal for asset allocation. Alternatively, a '''[[tactical asset allocation]]''' shifts allocations according to economic or valuation factors. Vanguard has historically used [[Tactical asset allocation#Vanguard tactical asset allocation funds|tactical asset allocation]] for a limited number of its balanced funds. Finally, a '''dynamic asset allocation''' shifts allocations in accordance with changing future liabilities. ==Stocks and bonds== {{Main|Stock basics | Bond basics}} You need [[Stock basics | stocks]] to get the expected return needed to accumulate funds for retirement. Stocks provide investors with a share of the profits generated by publicly owned companies in the economy. But in exchange for the hope of high return, stocks are extremely volatile and risky. Many investors learned how risky stocks can be in 2008 when they fell 50% from their previous highs. Over time, stock prices roughly follow the trend of the economy, which is to grow. But prices can stagnate or decline for decade-long periods. This is why an allocation to bonds is a necessary part of an asset allocation.{{cite web| author1=Joseph Davis| author2=Daniel Piquet| url=https://personal.vanguard.com/pdf/icrrbp.pdf| title=Recessions and balanced portfolio returns| date=2011| publisher=Vanguard Institutional| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210228023517/https://personal.vanguard.com/pdf/icrrbp.pdf| archive-date=February 28, 2021}} [[Bond basics | Bonds]] are a promise to pay back a loan of money on a pre-set schedule. Bonds do not produce the same expected high returns that stocks do, but they are much less volatile. The way to get reasonable growth without stomach-churning drops is to hold a mix of stocks and bonds. ==Impact of asset allocation on risk and return== {{quotation|In short, during the next 20 or 30 years, there will be a single, best allocation that in retrospect we will have wished we have owned. The only problem is that we haven't a clue what that portfolio will be. So, the safest course is to own as many asset classes as you can; that way you can be sure of avoiding the catastrophe of holding a portfolio concentrated in the worst ones.|author = [[William Bernstein|William J. Bernstein]]|source = The Four Pillars of Investing, pg 244, McGraw Hill}} The first table below shows the returns of various stock/bond allocations from 2000 - 2002. This period was marked by falling stock prices. The second table reflects the longer-term rewards investors hope to receive, assuming that the historical pattern of bond returns providing a premium return over inflation, and stock returns providing a premium over bond returns will be realized. The tables show why asset allocation is important. It determines future return, as well as the bear market burden of periodic losses that you will have to carry successfully to get those returns. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:Left" width="500px" ! colspan="2" |Cumulative return after inflation from 2000-to-2002 bear marketStock return from a Wilshire 5000 index fund; bond return from a Bloomberg Aggregate Bond Index fund; inflation data from US Treasury Department. |- |80% stock / 20% bond||-34.35% |- |70% stock / 30% bond||-25.81% |- |60% stock / 40% bond||-19.99% |- |50% stock / 50% bond||-13.87% |- |40% stock / 60% bond||-7.46% |- |30% stock / 70% bond||-0.74% |- |20% stock / 80% bond||+6.29% |} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:Left" width="500px" ! colspan="2" |Projected 10 year Cumulative return after inflation
stock return 8% yearly, bond return 4.5% yearly, inflation 3% yearlyInput parameters use exactly the same return rate each year, with no variations, no variance, no co-variance. This is a simplified calculation for illustrative purpose only; actual returns will vary. |- |80% stock / 20% bond||52% |- |70% stock / 30% bond||47% |- |60% stock / 40% bond||42% |- |50% stock / 50% bond||38% |- |40% stock / 60% bond||33% |- |30% stock / 70% bond||29% |- |20% stock / 80% bond||24% |} ==Rules of thumb== Although your exact asset allocation should depend on your goals for the money, there are some ''rules of thumb'' to help.Rule of thumb: A principle with broad application that is not intended to be strictly accurate or reliable for every situation. (Reference: {{forum link| p=1445012| title=Wiki: Asset Allocation - Update "Age in Bonds"?}}.) Any rule of thumb is only a starting point for decision making, not the end. The most important asset allocation decision is the split between risky and non-risky assets. This is most often referred to as the stock/bond split. [[Wikipedia:Benjamin Graham|Benjamin Graham]]'s timeless advice was:{{cite book|title=The Intelligent Investor |first=Benjamin |last=Graham |publisher=Collins Business |isbn=978-0060555665 |page=93 |edition=2003 edition annotated by Jason Zweig}}Also see: [[Graham 75-25 rule]] {{quotation|We have suggested as a fundamental guiding rule that the investor should never have less than 25% or more than 75% of his funds in common stocks, with a consequence inverse range of 75% to 25% in bonds. There is an implication here that the standard division should be an equal one, or 50-50, between the two major investment mediums.|Ben Graham|The Intelligent Investor}} [[John Bogle]] recommended "roughly your age in bonds"; for instance, at age 45, about 45% of the portfolio should be allocated to high-quality bonds. He also suggested that, during the retirement distribution phase, you should treat the value of any future pension and expected Social Security payments as a bond-like component of wealth and asset allocation. [[John Bogle | John C. Bogle]] elaborates his position, in the 2010 edition of ''Common Sense on Mutual Funds'', pp.87-88: {{blockquote|Long before the crash, I had fine-tuned my rule-of-thumb asset allocation model, centered at 50/50 for older investors in the distributions phase of their investment plan. Rather, I recommended -- as a crude starting point -- that an investor's bond position should be equal to his or her age. An investor age 65, then, would consider the propriety of a 65/35 bond/stock allocation. Clearly, such a rule must be adjusted to reflect an investor's objectives, risk tolerance, and overall financial position. (For example, pension and Social Security payments would be considered bondlike investments.) But the point is that as we age, we usually have (1) more wealth to protect, (2) less time to recoup severe losses, (3) greater need for income, and (4) perhaps an increased nervousness as markets jump around. All four of these factors suggest more bonds as we age.}} "Age in bonds" and its variants, (age - 10) or (age - 20), are very general rules of thumb which you can adjust for your circumstances; a key circumstance being the presence or absence of a pension, which would change your willingness or need to take risk. Some Bogleheads do not add pensions and Social Security to their asset allocation of bond holdings. (Reference: {{forum link| p=1445023| title=Wiki: Asset Allocation - Update "Age in Bonds"?}}.) If you choose less conservative guidelines, you should understand why you feel that you have the ''need, ability, and willingness'' to take on the greater inherent risk, as explained in the next section. All these age-based guidelines assume that your circumstances mirror the general population's. If you have a different retirement age (earlier or later), different asset levels (have saved enough to fund your retirement fully with [[Treasury Inflation Protected Security | TIPS]]), or different needs for the money (for example, college savings) you need to consider what makes your situation different, and adjust your asset allocation accordingly. ==Ability, willingness, and need== {{Main|Risk tolerance | Risk and return: an introduction}} Risk is the uncertainty (variation) of an investment's return. Risk tolerance is an investor’s emotional and psychological ability to endure investment losses during large market declines without selling or undue worry, such as losing sleep. To know whether an asset allocation is right for your risk tolerance, you need to be brutally honest with yourself as you try to answer the question, "Will I sell during the next bear market?". This is [[Risk_tolerance#Why_is_risk_tolerance_difficult_to_determine.3F|very hard to accurately assess]] before you have already gone through a bear market. Author [[Larry Swedroe]] has written a multi-part guide for selecting your asset allocation; how much to invest in stocks versus bonds. Four articles by Author [[Larry Swedroe]] are referenced here: *'''Part I:''' [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-how-much-risk-should-you-take/ Asset Allocation Guide: How much risk should you take?], CBS Moneywatch, February 3, 2014. *'''Part II:''' [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-what-is-your-risk-tolerance/ Asset Allocation Guide: What is your risk tolerance?], CBS Moneywatch, February 12, 2014. *'''Part III:''' [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-how-much-risk-do-you-need/ Asset Allocation Guide: How much risk do you need?], CBS Moneywatch, February 19, 2014. *'''Part IV:''' [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-dealing-with-conflicting-goals/ Asset Allocation Guide: Dealing with conflicting goals], CBS Moneywatch, February 25, 2014. There are three additional articles in the series: *'''Part V:''' [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-us-vs-international-equity/ Asset Allocation guide: U.S. vs. international equity], CBS Moneywatch, March 4, 2014. Determine the appropriate mix between domestic and international stocks. (This article is US focused.) *'''Part VI:''' [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-value-vs-growth/ Asset Allocation Guide: Value vs. growth], CBS Moneywatch, March 13, 2014. Decide how much to invest between ''value'' and ''growth'' stocks. (This article is intended for experienced investors who wish to deviate from the total market approach.) *'''Part VII:''' [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-small-cap-vs-large-cap/ Asset Allocation Guide: Small-cap vs. large-cap], CBS Moneywatch, March 18, 2014. Decide how much to invest between ''small-cap'' and ''large-cap'' stocks. (This article is intended for experienced investors who wish to deviate from the total market approach.) *'''Ability:''' Four factors determine your ''ability'' to take risk:''Ability'' relates to your capacity to withstand the ups and downs of the market without getting nervous and making changes to the asset allocation. Selling in the face of a decline is about the worst thing you can do. Here is a table offered by author [[Larry Swedroe]], based on the 1970s bear market, showing the amount of decline for various stock/bond allocations: {| | style="vertical-align:top;" | {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !Asset allocation %
(stock/bond) !Exposure to
maximum loss |- ||20/80||5% |- ||30/70||10% |- ||40/60||15% |- ||50/50||20% |- ||60/40||25% |} | style="vertical-align:top;" | {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !Asset allocation %
(stock/bond) !Exposure to
maximum loss |- ||70/30||30% |- ||80/20||35% |- ||90/10||40% |- ||100/0||50% |} |} For example, an investor would be willing to accept a loss of 35% in the portfolio if they held an allocation of (80% stocks / 20% bonds). This table is from the 1970s; performance during other time periods will have different results. The general idea is for investors to select an asset allocation they are comfortable with. Source: {{forum link| t=6211| title=Investment Planning}}.{{cite web| author=Larry Swedroe| author-link=Larry Swedroe| url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-how-much-risk-should-you-take/| title=Asset Allocation Guide: How much risk should you take?| publisher=CBS Moneywatch| date=February 3, 2014}} #Investment horizon - when do you need the money? #Stability of your earned income #The need for liquidity - if you need the money in a hurry #Your options if your existing plan fails to meet your objectives *'''Willingness:''' Define your ''willingness'' to take risk.{{cite web| author=Larry Swedroe| author-link=Larry Swedroe| url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-what-is-your-risk-tolerance/| title=Asset Allocation Guide: What is your risk tolerance?| publisher=CBS Moneywatch| date=February 12, 2014}} Do you have the fortitude and discipline to stick with your predetermined investment strategy when the going gets rough? *'''Need:''' The ''need'' to take risk is determined by the rate of return required to achieve financial objectives.{{cite web| author=Larry Swedroe| author-link=Larry Swedroe| url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-how-much-risk-do-you-need/| title=Asset Allocation Guide: How much risk do you need?| publisher=CBS Moneywatch| date=February 19, 2014}} The greater the rate of return needed to achieve your financial objective, the more risks with equities you need to take. A critical part of the process is differentiating between real needs and desires. If you decide to take more risk because of perceived "need", keep in mind that taking extra risk could well backfire and lead to lower returns. *How you should handle difficult choices among ''ability'', ''willingness'', and ''need'' to take risk.{{cite web| author=Larry Swedroe| author-link=Larry Swedroe| url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/asset-allocation-guide-dealing-with-conflicting-goals/| title=Asset Allocation Guide: Dealing with conflicting goals| publisher=CBS Moneywatch| date=February 25, 2014}} In general, [[Larry Swedroe]] suggests choosing the lowest equity allocation from among ''ability'', ''willingness'', and ''need'' to take risk (and adjusting goals as needed).{{Forum link|p=6032412|title=Re: Clarification of the 'need, ability, and willingness' framework}} In the case where the ''ability'' is greater than the ''need'' to take risk, it is possible to choose an equity allocation in the range between these two factors, based on your ''willingness'' to take risk. ==Rebalancing== {{Main|Rebalancing}} Over time your asset allocation may change from its original position as a result of the difference in returns from the various asset classes. [[Rebalancing]] is the act of bringing the asset allocation in line with current [[investment policy statement|investment policy]]. A typical recommendation is that you should review the portfolio asset allocation once a year, and if necessary, rebalance as specified in the investment policy. Rebalancing is often the most difficult part because it is counterintuitive, it requires you to sell a portion of an investment that went up, and buy more of what went down.{{cite book|author=Rick Ferri| author-link=Rick Ferri| title=All About Asset Allocation: The Easy Way to Get Started|edition=Second|date=2010|page=x|publisher=McGraw-Hill, Inc|isbn=978-0071700788}} ==Asset allocation portfolios== {{Main|Lazy portfolios}} Strategic asset allocation strategies range from simple to complex. [[Lazy portfolios]] are designed to perform well in most market conditions. Most contain a small number of low-cost funds that are easy to rebalance. They are "lazy" in that you can maintain the same asset allocation for an extended period of time, suitable for most pre-retirement investors. *[[John Bogle]] was a proponent of simple asset allocation portfolios. He frequently advised that most investors should allocate investment portfolios using two asset class index funds: a U.S. total market stock index fund, and a U.S. total bond market index fund.John Bogle argues this position in his classic text, {{cite book| title=Common Sense on Mutual Funds| isbn=978-0470138137}} *A widely held portfolio among Bogleheads Forum members is the [[three fund portfolio]]. This allocates investments among a U.S. Total market stock market portfolio; a Total International stock market portfolio, and a U.S Total bond market portfolio. Members frequently expand this portfolio to include a fourth asset class, [[Treasury Inflation Protected Securities|U.S. inflation-indexed bonds]]. *Some strategic asset allocation funds add additional asset classes or sub-asset classes to the asset mix. For equity investments these additions can include [[Value tilting - stock|value stock]] funds, real estate funds ([[Real estate investment trust|U.S.]] and [[International REITs|international]]), [[gold]], and [[Commodities|commodity]] futures funds. Additional fixed income asset classes include [[High yield bonds|U.S high yield bond]] funds, international [[Developed market bonds|developed market bond]] funds, and [[Emerging market bonds|emerging market bond]] funds. Depending on your risk tolerance preferences or tax situation, you might restrict your bond market allocations to [[treasury bonds|U.S treasury bonds]] or investment grade [[municipal bonds]]. File:Lazy3.PNG|Three fund portfolio File:Core_Four_60_40.PNG|Ferri Core four portfolio File:CoffeeHouse_Portfolio.PNG |Schultheis Coffeehouse portfolio File:Armstrong_Ideal_Index_Portfolio.PNG|Armstrong Ideal Index portfolio ==Funds that implement target asset allocations== {{Main|Balanced fund|Target date funds}} An asset-allocation fund or a balanced fund is a [[mutual fund]] that holds multiple [[Asset class | asset classes]]. Typically these funds hold [[Stock basics|stocks]], [[Bond basics|bonds]], and in some instances, [[Money markets|cash]]. Although many balanced funds maintain a fixed [[ asset allocation]], some have a variable allocation policy, changing asset weightings according to market conditions. [[Target date funds]] are balanced funds that gradually change asset class weightings according to a presumed changing need for a lower risk profile over time. These funds attempt to provide investors portfolios that account for the holder's age, risk appetite, and investment objectives, with an appropriate allocation of asset classes. However, [[Balanced fund#Arguments against balanced funds|critics of this approach]] point out that arriving at a standardized solution for allocating portfolio assets is problematic because individual investors require individual solutions. ==Choices for equity== {{See also|Variations on Bogleheads® investing}} For equity allocation, you need to choose the split between domestic ("US") and international (excluding US or "ex-US") stocks. You may decide to select a set portion of regional stock markets, for example: North American markets, European markets, Asian markets, and Emerging markets. If you are unsure of the US and ex-US allocation split (the sum representing the total amount of stocks), you can copy the allocations used by a balanced ("all-in-one") or target date fund. Those funds are created by experienced professionals who have done all the hard work before-hand. An example is shown in the wiki [[Approximating Vanguard target date funds#Example of approximating a Vanguard target date fund |here]]. At the same time, you need to decide whether to follow the full market or to select a portion (large-cap, mid-cap or small-cap); or to tilt in style (value, blend or growth); favor [[REIT]]s, or to allocate among sectors. A common reasons for sector allocation is: You may be employed in a segment of the economy with low job security and so want to reduce or eliminate exposure to that sector in your investment portfolio. ==Choices for bonds== Bogleheads like to own bond funds [[Individual Bonds vs a Bond Fund | instead of individual bonds]] for convenience and diversification. Using individual [[Corporate bonds|corporate]] or [[Municipal bonds|municipal]] bonds require a very large holding in order to achieve the broad diversification and increased safety of a bond fund. The high number of different bonds in bond funds let you ignore the risk of any one bond defaulting. You can manage [[Bond basics#Interest rate risk|Interest rate risk]] if you select funds with short and intermediate-term [[Bonds: advanced topics#Duration |duration]], and you can manage [[Bond basics#Credit_risk| default risk]] by selecting funds with high credit ratings. The central idea here is that your bond holdings are for safety; that is, to reduce violent up and down swings in your overall portfolio value. Bogleheads tend to take risks on the equity side, not the bond side. Bogleheads typically divide bond allocations between just two categories: [[Nominal bond | nominal bonds]] such as the [{{Vf | 0084}} Vanguard Total Bond Market Fund], and U.S. Treasury Inflation Protected Securities ([[Treasury Inflation Protected Security |TIPS]]) such as the [{{Vf | 0119}} Vanguard Inflation Protected Securities Fund]. A TIPS fund gives you additional diversification, as well as inflation protection.{{cite book| title=The Bogleheads' Guide To Investing| title-link=Bogleheads' Guide To Investing| isbn=978-1-118-92128-9| publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.| date=2007| p=103}} [[I Savings Bonds | I-Bonds]] are also an attractive alternative to TIPS. The U.S. Treasury sells these directly to investors. They do not need to be held in a tax-protected account; and they accrue interest tax-deferred for up to 30 years. There are annual limits on how much you can buy in I-bonds. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==See also== *[[Asset allocation in multiple accounts]] *[[:Category:Asset classes | Asset classes (category)]] *[[:Category:Asset allocation | Asset allocation (category)]] *[[Bogleheads® investing start-up kit]] *[[Bogleheads investment philosophy#Diversify | Bogleheads investment philosophy]] *[[Variations on Bogleheads® investing]] *[[Lazy portfolios]] *[[Tactical asset allocation]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== ===Importance of asset allocation=== *Gary P. The '''{{PAGENAME}}''' is a portfolio proposed by [[William F. Sharpe]]. It consists of global stocks and bonds, held in [[Free-float methodology|free-float]] market proportions.<ref name=RISMAT-7>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Retirement Income Scenario Matrices 7. The Market Portfolio|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/RISMAT-7.pdf|publisher=Stanford University (Creative Commons)|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref>
== Components ==
There is currently no single retail fund that implements a World Bond/Stock (WBS) portfolio in the way described by Sharpe. To address this, he has suggested a four-fund proxy<ref name=RISMAT-7/><ref name=4-Fund-Proxy>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=The Four-fund Proxy for the World Bond Stock Fund|url=https://retirementincomeanalysis.blogspot.com/2019/08/the-four-fund-proxy-for-wold-bond-stock.html|date=August 2019|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> and also a two-fund proxy<ref name=2-Fund-Proxy>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=A Two-fund Proxy for the World Bond Stock Fund|url=https://retirementincomeanalysis.blogspot.com/2019/09/a-two-fund-proxy-for-world-bond-stock.html|date=September 2019|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> for WBS consisting of established Vanguard index funds.
A four-fund proxy for WBS consists of:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund !! Asset class |- | VTSAX (or VTI) || US stocks |- | VTIAX (or VXUS) || Ex-US stocks |- | VBTLX (or BND) || USD bonds |- | VTABX (or BNDX) || Ex-USD bonds |- |}
A two-fund proxy for WBS consists of:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund !! Asset class |- | VT || Global stocks |- | BNDW || Global bonds |- |}
Of course, it is also possible to implement something similar with non-Vanguard funds.
== Allocations ==
The index funds used by the WBS proxies described above are held in proportion to their free-float market capitalization. That requires calculating the market capitalization of the index that each fund tracks. This is done by taking each index's market capitalization listed in its most recent factsheet, and then projecting that forward by the change in the fund's adjusted closing prices between the factsheet's publishing date and the current date.
<math> \mathrm{IndexMarketCap}_\mathrm{Current} = \mathrm{IndexMarketCap}_\mathrm{Factsheet} \times \frac{\mathrm{TrackingFundPrice}_\mathrm{Current}}{\mathrm{TrackingFundPrice}_{\mathrm{FactsheetDate}}} </math>
Note: VBTLX/BND, VTABX/BNDX, and BNDW track Bloomberg indices which do not publish their market capitalization numbers. Sharpe has suggested that FTSE indexes (for example, WorldBIG) could substitute.<ref name=RISMAT-7/><ref name=4-Fund-Proxy/>
=== Example ===
Here is an example of the allocation calculations as of June 15, 2025:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund ! Asset class ! Tracked index ! Index factsheet market cap ! Index factsheet date ! Adjusted closing price on factsheet date ! Latest adjusted closing price (June 15, 2025) ! Projected market cap (June 15, 2025) ! Allocation (June 15, 2025) |- | VT | Global stocks | FTSE Global All Cap Index | $90.42T | May 30, 2025 | $123.37 | $124.95 | $91.58T (= $90.42T * $124.95 / $123.37) | 62.43% (= $91.58T / ($55.08T + $91.58T)) |- | BNDW | Global bonds | FTSE WorldBIG (substitute for Bloomberg index) | $54.93T | May 31, 2025 | $68.58 | $68.77 | $55.08T (= $54.93T * $68.77 / $68.58) | 37.57% (= $55.08T / ($55.08T + $91.58T)) |- |}
=== Current allocations ===
Here are the current allocations for the four-fund proxy, updated in real time:
{| border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; |- |{{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=2PACX-1vQShEGnLTHNk2_zgHWTiReXADEhmNvLR8SIaTsdGTdQJaa_F9ESrbo8bcsP0XEsVlBFtGEbjqUMO7g_ |oid=1905516517 |width=450 |height=280 }} |- |Source: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VFfGgf-oscxsnyjHLsdIGNa5WfxI00XG_51xxr5VUn4/edit#gid=717958008 GMP: Global Market Portfolio] |}
Here are the current allocations for the two-fund proxy, updated in real time:
{| border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; |- |{{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=2PACX-1vQShEGnLTHNk2_zgHWTiReXADEhmNvLR8SIaTsdGTdQJaa_F9ESrbo8bcsP0XEsVlBFtGEbjqUMO7g_ |oid=912172076 |width=450 |height=280 }} |- |Source: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VFfGgf-oscxsnyjHLsdIGNa5WfxI00XG_51xxr5VUn4/edit#gid=717958008 GMP: Global Market Portfolio] |}
Note: The total allocation to VTI and VXUS in the four-fund proxy might not precisely equal the VT allocation in the two-fund proxy. This is because VTI tracks a [[CRSP equity indexes|CRSP]] index which differs slightly from the [[FTSE Group|FTSE]] index that VT tracks.
== Rebalancing == {{See also|Rebalancing}}
The World Bond/Stock (WBS) portfolio holds each individual asset (that is, individual stock or bond) in proportion to its free-float market capitalization. Equivalently, it holds the same fraction of each asset’s free-float shares outstanding. That is, '''(shares held) / (free-float shares outstanding)''' is the same for every individual asset.
Framing WBS this way shows that rebalancing is needed only when an asset’s free-float supply changes the fraction of shares held (for example, new issuances, buybacks, or redemptions).
Conversely, events like price changes and dividend payments do ''not'' require rebalancing since they leave the fraction of shares held unchanged. As a result, WBS requires less frequent rebalancing than traditional fixed-weight portfolios (for example, a 60/40 stock/bond mix), which must rebalance whenever asset prices change.
If WBS assets are held through a ''single'' index fund, the fund handles rebalancing internally. But if assets are split across ''multiple funds'' (for example, stocks in VT and bonds in BNDW), their underlying free-float supply may change at different rates. This causes the share fractions held by the different funds to drift apart, requiring occasional manual rebalancing between the funds to realign them.
== Adjusting for personal circumstances ==
The World Bond/Stock portfolio mirrors the holdings of the average publicly invested portfolio, thereby taking on average investment risk and producing average return.<ref name=Arithmetic>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=The Arithmetic of Active Management|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/art/active/active.htm|publisher=Association for Investment Management and Research|date=February 1991|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> This makes it a good default strategy.
Nevertheless, Sharpe notes that someone may justifiably deviate from this strategy to adjust for personal circumstances.<ref name=Adjust>{{Cite web|author=Charles Rotblut, William F. Sharpe|title=Allocate by Market Weight (And Adjust for Personal Circumstances)|url=https://www.aaii.com/files/PDF/9314_allocate-by-market-weight-and-adjust-for-personal-circumstances.pdf|publisher=American Association of Individual Investors|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> Adjustments discussed by Sharpe include: * '''Adding a riskless asset.''' For example, using certain inflation-adjusted investments (like [[Treasury Inflation Protected Security|TIPS]]) to cover a portion of real expenses.<ref name=RISMAT-6>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Retirement Income Analysis with scenario matrices, Chapter 6. Inflation-Protected Investments|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/RISMAT-6.pdf|publisher=Stanford University (Creative Commons)|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> * '''Tilting asset allocations.''' For example, adjusting the stock/bond ratio to account for factors like [[Human capital|human capital]].<ref name=Adjust/>
=== Tilting using adaptive asset allocation ===
Sharpe proposes Adaptive Asset Allocation Policies, which allow asset class tilting while still remaining anchored to the dynamics of the WBS portfolio.<ref name=AAAP>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Adaptive Asset Allocation Policies |url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/aaap/wfsaaap.pdf|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> This enables customization while continuously adapting to changes in the relative risk between asset classes.
It works as follows. Start with a desired initial allocation. Then update each asset class weight using:
<math> \mathrm{UpdatedWeight} = \mathrm{CurrentMarketWeight} \times \frac{\mathrm{InitialDesiredWeight}}{\mathrm{InitialMarketWeight}} </math>
Finally, normalize the updated weights to get the new allocation. For example:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund ! Asset class ! Initial desired weight ! Initial market weight ! Current market weight ! Updated weight ! Normalized allocation |- | VT | Global stocks | 80% | 60% | 55% | 73.33% (= 55% * 80/60) | 76.52% (= 73.33 / (73.33 + 22.50)) |- | BNDW | Global bonds | 20% | 40% | 45% | 22.50% (=45% * 20/40) | 23.48% (= 22.50 / (73.33 + 22.50)) |- |}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/ Retirement Income Analysis With Scenario Matrices (RISMAT)], William F. {{Warning| The concept of portfolio '''value tilting''' is intended for advanced investors. Tilting is not recommended for new investors, as it ''intentionally deviates'' from investing in the total market- a Bogleheads' approach to managing your portfolio. }} ==Background== {{Quote |quote = '''John Bogle on tilting''':
"Impressed both by the long-term performance (and recent performance) of value stocks and small-cap stocks, some investors hold the all-market (or S&P 500) index fund as the core, and add a value index fund and a small-cap index fund as satellites. I'm skeptical that any kind of superior performance will endure forever. (Nothing does!) But if you disagree, it would not be unreasonable to hold, say, 85 percent in the core, another 10 percent in value, and another 5 percent in small cap. But doing so increases the risk that your return will fall short of the market's return, so don't push too far." |source = -- ''The Little Book Of Common Sense Investing'', p.206. }} Financial expertsSee John Bogle, [https://personal.vanguard.com/bogle_site/sp20020626.html The Telltale Chart] often recommend that investors should use index mutual funds to invest in entire markets, or, invest in funds that approximate the total market. Other portfolio theorists advise holding portfolios that tilt toward small and value stocks.Eugene Fama Jr., [http://www.dfaus.com/2009/05/the-new-indexing.html The New Indexing], July 2000.Truman A. Clark, [http://www.dfaus.com/2009/05/the-dimensions-of-stock-returns-2007.html The Dimensions of Stock Returns], September 2007. One popular way to analyze the stock market is to subdivide it into 3 levels of [[Market Capitalization | market capitalization]] and 3 [[Stock Basics#Style | styles]], resulting in a 3 x 3 "style" box. As defined in the style box for VTSMX[{{Vf | 0085}} Vanguard's Total Stock Market Index Fund (VTSMX)] approximates the total market by investing in over 3,000 stocks, which is representative of the whole U.S. market, the majority of the US Market (the Total Stock Market or "TSM") is held in large caps. Therefore, this fund (representing the US Market, or the "Market") is defined as a "''cap weighted''" market.
{| {{table}} |+ '''Total Stock Market Index Fund Style Box (%)''' | | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Value''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Blend''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Growth''' |- | align="right" style="background:#f0f0f0;" | '''Large Cap'''||align="center" | 26||align="center" |22||align="center" |24 |- | align="right" style="background:#f0f0f0;" |'''Mid Cap'''||align="center" |6||align="center" |6||align="center" |7 |- | align="right" style="background:#f0f0f0;" |'''Small Cap'''||align="center" |3||align="center" |3||align="center" |3 |}
The intent is that these distribution percentages, by definition, accurately represent the composition of the entire market. Gain and loss over time represents the movement of the market as a whole. If you invest $1.00 in a total market index fund, each stock receives the same amount of your dollar in proportion to its cap weight. The largest stock gets 100 times the amount of a company 100th its size. Therefore, no company gets more or less than that determined by its market capitalization. ==Tilting== Tilting is defined as any deviation (change) from the Total Stock Market distribution percentages as previously defined. Historically, value stocks and small stocks have provided higher returns than large blend and growth stocks (in both domestic and foreign markets). The theoretical basis posited for these higher returns states that small stocks and value stocks are riskier than large and growth stocks, and that the higher returns compensate investors for higher risk. Rolf W. Banz, "The Relationship Between Return and Market Value of Common Stocks," Journal of Financial Economics, 9 (1981), pp. 3-18 Davis, James L., [[Eugene F. Fama]] and [[Kenneth R. French]], "Characteristics, Covariances, and Average Returns: 1929-1997" (February 1999). Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) Working Paper No. 471. Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=98678 or DOI: 10.2139/ssrn.98678 [[Eugene F. Fama]] and [[Kenneth R. French]], "Value Versus Growth: The International Evidence" (August 1997). Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=2358 or DOI: 10.2139/ssrn.2358 Based on theory and past performance, some investors choose to add additional value and small stocks to their portfolios. Many investors who tilt employ what is termed a 4x25 allocation consisting of equal parts of 25% large blend; 25% large value; 25% small blend; and 25% small value. Tilters employ blend indexes for growth stock exposure in response to the long term performance of small cap growth stocks. [[William Bernstein]], [http://www.efficientfrontier.com/ef/499/scg.htm Small Cap Growth Indexing and the Multifactor Threestep],''Efficient Frontier'', April, 1999. [[William Bernstein]], [http://www.efficientfrontier.com/ef/701/sg.htm The Small-Growth Indexing Anomaly], ''Efficient Frontier'', Summer 2001. Other tilters, valuing greater portfolio simplicity, overweight small value stocks by adding a small value fund to the market portfolio.Sample portfolios using small cap tilts are included in [[Lazy Portfolios]]: *[[Lazy Portfolios#Bill Schultheis's "Coffeehouse" Portfolio]] *[[Lazy Portfolios#William Bernstein's "Coward's" Portfolio]] *[[Lazy Portfolios#Frank Armstrong's "Ideal Index" Portfolio]] Overweight means increasing your holdings to more than is naturally in the market profile. As an example, the Small cap styles represent 9% (3 + 3 + 3) of the total market. ''Tilting to Small'' means overweighting your portfolio to hold more than 9% of Small cap stocks. ==Considerations== ===Asset allocation=== Bogleheads author [[Larry Swedroe]] suggests that tilting to stocks with higher expected returns, such as small-cap and value, can allow the investor reduce overall equity exposure while maintaining the same expected return for the portfolio. Holding a smaller allocation to stocks and a larger allocation to bonds reduces "fat tail" risk; i.e., the risk of unexpected events that have a large negative impact on the overall stock market. ===Duration=== Tilted portfolios require long holding periods as the market, value, and size factor returns often rotate over time. [[William Bernstein]], [http://www.efficientfrontier.com/ef/700/factors.htm Factor Rotation], ''Efficient Frontier'', Summer 2000. ===Investor behavior=== The investor's behavior during bear and bull markets can influence results. An investor who tilts must be able to hold to the allocation during periods when the tilted equity portfolio underperforms the market portfolio. An investor should also resist the temptation to engage in "performance chasing", that is buying or selling a size or style tilt based on recent performance. ===Rate of return=== Although small-cap and value stocks may have higher expected returns than large-cap and growth stocks, investors should recognize that the record of realized returns does not assure a similar pattern in the future. The timing and magnitude of the small and value premiums will always be uncertain, i.e. past performance does not predict future performance. ===Taxes=== In a taxable account, value funds have an additional tax cost, because they tend to have higher dividend yields. Rebalancing between multiple funds may also add to the tax cost if the rebalancing cannot be done with new money. Small-cap and value index funds are more likely to realize capital gains, although tax-managed funds and [[ETFs]] reduce this tax effect. Much of the extra tax cost can be avoided by [[Principles of Tax-Efficient Fund Placement|tax-efficient fund placement]] for an investor with both tax-advantaged and taxable accounts if the value funds can all be held in a tax-advantaged account. ==See also== *[[FAQ small cap funds]] *[[Slice and dice]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *Remarks by John Bogle regarding the stock market and Reversion to the Mean (RTM): :*[http://www.vanguard.com/bogle_site/sp20010215.html The Stock Market Universe—Stars, Comets, and the Sun] :*[http://www.vanguard.com/bogle_site/sp20020626.html The Telltale Chart] *[http://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=35493 value tilting: the numbers], forum discussion *[http://homepage.mac.com/j.norstad/finance/total.html Investing in Total Markets], Pros and cons of investing in the Total Market, Efficient Market Hypothesis / Theory *[http://www.investopedia.com/articles/05/021705.asp Achieving Better Returns In Your Portfolio], Investopedia tutorial on the Fama / French 3-Factor model and a brief insight into tilting *[http://www.dfaus.com/2009/05/the-dimensions-of-stock-returns-2007.html The Dimensions of Stock Returns: 2007], from [http://www.dfaus.com/ Dimensional Fund Advisors] *[http://www.dfaus.com/2009/05/the-new-indexing.html The New Indexing], from [http://www.dfaus.com/ Dimensional Fund Advisors] *[http://www.dfaus.com/2009/05/the-informational-efficiency-of-stock-prices-a-review.html The Informational Efficiency of Stock Prices: A Review], from [http://www.dfaus.com/ Dimensional Fund Advisors] [[Category:US stocks]] [[Category:Non-US stocks]] [[Category:Portfolios]]

'''{{PAGENAME}}''' (DCA) means dividing an available investment lump sum into equal parts, and then periodically investing each part.The origin of the term '''Dollar cost averaging''' (DCA) is the distinction between a practice of buying a fixed number of shares every period and a practice of investing a fixed dollar amount every period. Over time the meaning has been extended. DCA is an alternative to lump sum investing, which is to make the entire investment immediately. It is a technique to overcome fear in investing by mitigating the risk of loss over the short term. For any sequence of constant-dollar purchasesEqual parts means that the amount (dollars) is constant, hence the term "constant-dollar". of an asset whose price fluctuates, you would purchase more shares when prices are lower than when prices are high.{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/d/dollarcostaveraging.asp| title=Dollar-Cost Averaging (DCA) Explained With Examples and Considerations| publisher=Investopedia| date=April 26, 2023| accessdate=August 12, 2023}} As a result, the average cost per share will be lower than the average price per share over the same period. This consequence of DCA provides an argument to persuade investors to make systematic, periodic fixed dollar amount investments regardless of market prices. The term DCA is also encompasses similar investment concepts such as [[#Automatic investment|periodic automatic investment]] (used almost universally by individual investors to fund retirement accounts out of earned income). A variant on the idea of DCA is "[[#Reverse dollar cost averaging|reverse dollar-cost averaging]]", which relates to periodic automatic withdrawals made during retirement.{{cite web| url=http://www.analyzenow.com/Articles/Investments/Investment%20Articles/ReverseDollarCostAvg1-1-01.pdf| title=Reverse Dollar Cost Averaging| author=Henry K. Hebeler| date=January 2, 2001| accessdate=August 12, 2023}} Also, [[value averaging]] closely resembles dollar-cost averaging but differs in that the investor selects a target growth rate or amount on their asset base or portfolio each period, and then adjusts the next period's contribution according to the relative gain or shortfall made on the original asset base.{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/v/value_averaging.asp| title=Value Averaging: What it Means, Examples| publisher=Investopedia| date=May 5, 2022| accessdate=August 12, 2023}} ==Dollar-cost averaging versus lump sum== When you are ready to invest money, a common question is whether you should invest it as a '''lump sum''' or '''dollar-cost average (DCA)''' by splitting your investment across several payments. The answer depends on the degree to which you are willing to accept lower expected returns in exchange for lower potential losses (aversion to possible loss). In most cases, you are moving your money from cash (or the equivalent, a low-yielding [[Money markets | money market]]) to some mix of [[Stock basics | stocks]] and [[Bond basics | bonds]]. The expected return of both stocks and bonds is higher than cash. However, their volatility is higher as well. The risk is that just after making your investment, the market could crash, causing your investment to quickly lose value due to the unfortunate timing of your purchase. Of course, according to [[Bogleheads® investment philosophy | Bogleheads investment philosophy]], you should only be investing in the first place into a diversified asset allocation. Also, you should only be holding volatile funds like stocks and bonds if your investing horizon is long enough to ride out their volatility. Lump sum investing will always carry a higher expected return, because it immediately moves your funds from asset classes with lower expected returns to ones with higher expected returns. Note that higher ''expected'' returns do not guarantee that your ''actual'' returns will be higher. A Vanguard study {{cite web| url=https://pressroom.vanguard.com/nonindexed/7.23.2012_Dollar-cost_Averaging.pdf| title=Dollar-cost averaging just means taking risk later| publisher=Vanguard| date=July 23, 2012| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107195530/https://pressroom.vanguard.com/nonindexed/7.23.2012_Dollar-cost_Averaging.pdf| archive-date=November 7, 2012}} concluded that lump sum investing has historically produced higher returns two thirds of the time when the DCA plan was implemented over 12 months. Lump sum was also more favorable when the analysis used risk-adjusted returns. DCA plans with longer timelines have worse results. A related Vanguard publication notes that if a DCA plan was implemented over 36 months, lump sum investing produced higher returns approximately 92% of the time. In addition, over a 12-month period, the maximum downside potential of DCA was higher than the maximum upside potential.{{Cite web|last=Berkowitz|first=Daniel B.|date=2016|title=Invest now or temporarily hold your cash?|url=https://www.optimizedportfolio.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/vanguard-invest-now-or-temporarily-hold-your-cash.pdf|publisher=Vanguard}} Some investors are willing to sacrifice some expected return in order to reduce their potential loss, knowing that higher expected return come with higher potential loss. For those investors, dollar-cost averaging is superior because it reduces the chances of investing all the money just prior to a market drop. Instead, as the price fluctuates each month, you will buy more shares when the price is low and less when it is high. In such volatile markets your actual return can be higher than the return of the lumpsum which will match the return of the assets. Many new investors are more interested in minimizing their potential loss, and it is important that an ill-timed market drop does not scare them off from investing in the future. Many experienced investors are more interested in maximizing their expected returns. You can also decide to split the difference, where you invest half immediately and the other half over 6 or so months. === Costs=== Most no-load mutual funds allow small, regular investments with no fees. However, most investors pay a commission to purchase a load-fund or an [[Exchange-traded fund]] (ETF). Depending on the size of the commission and the investment, dollar-cost averaging into a load-fund or an ETF could be far more expensive than purchasing as a lump sum. For ETFs, the [[bid/ask spread]] is the same between DCA and lump sum. ==Automatic investment== Most investors make regular contributions through their [[401(k)]] plans or by having a set amount auto-deducted from their bank account into an [[IRA]] or taxable account. When this money is automatically invested, it has the same benefit of dollar-cost averaging that you buy more shares when prices are low and less when they are high. However, this form of investing is not dollar-cost averaging. It is called '''periodic investing'''. The difference is that periodic investing is maximizing expected return, because you are investing the money as soon as you have it. DCA applies when you have the money to invest, but delay doing so. ===Switching to a more conservative portfolio=== Some investors who are new to a [[Bogleheads® investment philosophy | Bogleheads investment philosophy]] may find their portfolios contain too much equity. Even worse, some investors have a large portion of their net worth held in a single stock, such as through an employee purchase plan. They generally want to sell some of their equities and buy bonds. In these cases where an investor wants to move from high risk and volatility assets to lower risk and volatility assets, a lump sum transaction makes more sense than DCA. That is because lump sum both immediately moves to the expected return and volatility the investor wants, while also minimizing potential regret. ==Reverse dollar-cost averaging== Investors who regularly add to their investment portfolios with '''periodic investing''' purchase more shares when prices are low and less shares when prices are high. Author Henry K. Hebeler{{cite book| author=Henry K. Hebeler |title=Getting Started in A Financially Secure Retirement| publisher=John Wiley & Sons| date=April 27, 2007| isbn=978-0-470-11778-1}} points out that investors ''' periodically distributing''' retirement income from their portfolios experience the reverse action, redeeming more shares when prices are low and less shares when prices are high. Hebeler terms this process, "reverse dollar-cost averaging" with results that should, on average, reduce expected returns. Examining rolling 20 year investment periods from 1927 to 1995 for a portfolio consisting of 50% large cap stocks ([[S&P 500 index|S&P 500]]); 40% long term [[Corporate bonds|corporate bonds]]; and 10% [[Treasury bill|treasury bills]], with expense loadings of 1.50% for stocks; 0.50% for bonds; and 0.30% for cash), Hebeler provides average real returns for four scenarios: the portfolio; the accumulating investor (saving for retirement); the distributing investor (withdrawal during retirement); as well as the results of 80% percentile returns (reflecting desires for portfolio survivability for retirement distributions). Indexing the portfolios would add 0.70% to each portfolio's returns simply due to reduced costs. {| class="wikitable" |- |+Average real returns (rolling 20 years) 1927-1995 ! !Portfolio return
50% stock/40% bond/10% cash ! Accumulating investor !Distributing investor |- |Portfolio | align="center" |2.9% | align="center" |3.2% | align="center" |2.6% |- |80 percentile | align="center" |1.2% | align="center" |0.8% | align="center" |0.3% |} ==Notes == {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==See also== *[[Value averaging]] *[[Lump sum vs pension]] ==References== {{Reflist|}} ==External links== *[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283358689_A_behavioral_framework_for_dollar-cost_averaging_Dollar-cost_averaging_may_not_be_rational_behavior_but_it_is_perfectly_normal_behavior A behavioral framework for dollar-cost averaging: Dollar-cost averaging may not be rational behavior, but it is perfectly normal behavior], Meir Statman, Journal of Portfolio Management Volume 22, pages 70-78, January 1995. *[https://blog.wealthfront.com/dollar-cost-averaging-behavioral-view/ Dollar Cost Averaging: A Behavioral View], Meir Statman, Wealthfront Blog, June 18, 2015. *[http://www.dimensional.com/famafrench/2009/06/dollar-cost-averaging.html Dollar Cost Averaging],{{dead link}} Fama/French Forum video. *[http://www.moneychimp.com/features/dollar_cost.htm Does Dollar Cost Averaging Really Work], DCA calculator, moneychimp. *[http://www.efficientfrontier.com/ef/997/dca.htm Do Not Dollar-Cost-Average for More than Twelve Months], Bill Jones, Efficient Frontier, October 1997. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20210812193032/http://www.sigmainvesting.com/advanced-investing-topics/dollar-cost-averaging Dollar Cost Averaging], detailed examination by Sigma Investing. *{{Forum link| t=83767| title=Finally! Can we lay DCA to rest and ban this topic forever?| date=October 7, 2011}}. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20170215161450/https://personal.vanguard.com/pdf/ISGDCA.pdf Invest now or temporarily hold your cash?], 2016 Vanguard paper comparing DCA to lump sum investing. *[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/take-plunge-or-drip-by-drip/ Take the plunge, or drip by drip?], CBS MoneyWatch article by [[Larry Swedroe]], January 3, 2014. *[https://www.forbes.com/sites/rickferri/2015/09/08/6-things-to-consider-when-investing-a-lump-sum/ 6 Things To Consider When Investing a Lump Sum], [[:Rick Ferri]], Forbes, September 8, 2015. *[https://awealthofcommonsense.com/2014/02/worlds-worst-market-timer/ What if You Only Invested at Market Peaks?], by Ben Carlson on [https://awealthofcommonsense.com awealthofcommonsense.com]. ===Bibliography=== {| border="0" || * Constantinides, George M., ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20190412180131/http://faculty.chicagobooth.edu/george.constantinides/documents/JFQA_1979.pdf A Note on the Suboptimality of Dollar-Cost Averaging as an Investment Policy]'', Journal of Financial and Quantitative Analysis 14 (June 1979), 443-49. *Fang, Wei, ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20140123220801/http://www.valueaveraging.ca:80/docs/DCA%20Investigation%20Study.pdf Dollar-cost Averaging: An Investigation]'', The University of Nottingham, 2007 *Hayley, Simon, ''[https://ssrn.com/abstract=1606347 Value Averaging and the Automated Bias of Performance Measures]'', (March 11, 2011). Available at SSRN. *Johnson,Kim and Kruegar, Tom, ''[https://www.valueaveraging.ca/docs/Analysis_Dollar_Cost_Averaging.pdf Market Timing versus Dollar-Cost Averaging: Evidence based on Two Decades of Standard & Poor’s 500 Index Values]'' *Knight, John K., and Marshall, Lewis, ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20140924161913/http://www.valueaveraging.ca/docs/Nobody%20Gains%20from%20DCA.pdf Nobody Gains from DCA], Financial Services Review, 2(1): 51-61.'' *Leggio, Karyl B, and Lien, Donald, ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20140916164735/http://valueaveraging.ca/docs/DCA%20Losses.pdf Does loss aversion explain dollar cost averaging?]'', Financial Services Review, 10(2001): 117-127. *Marshall, Paul S., ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20110814011724/http://www.studyfinance.com/jfsd/pdffiles/v13n1/marshall.pdf A Statistical Comparison Of Value Averaging vs. Dollar Cost Averaging and Random Investment Techniques]'', Journal of Financial and Strategic Decisions Volume 13, Number 1, Spring 2000. * Trainor, William J., Jr. ''[http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.392.2893&rep=rep1&type=pdf Within-horizon exposure to loss for dollar cost averaging and lump sum investing]'', Financial Services Review 14 (2005) 319–330. |} {{Portfolios}} [[Category:Portfolios]]

{{Notice| ''Value Averaging'' is for experienced investors. You may need to hold funds in reserve, such as a money market fund, to cover additional contributions needed during market declines. Managing this cash flow adds further complications. Please ask in the forum for assistance. }} '''{{PAGENAME}}''' uses a formula, shown below, to guide how much you invest into a given investment at a specific time. The emphasis is on establishing a portfolio target value or "value path". Value averaging aims to periodically increase the investment's value by this calculated amount. Whenever a portfolio under-performs, you will have to make a larger investment to make up for the under-performance. The converse is also true, so that if the portfolio outperforms its targeted rate of return, then then you do not purchase more shares. You can think of value averaging as a combination of [[dollar cost averaging]] and portfolio [[rebalancing]].{{cite web| url=https://www.valueaveraging.ca/research/The%20Value%20Averaging%20Investment%20Strategy.pdf| author=Bruce Ramsey| title=The Value Averaging Investment Strategy| publisher=VA Investment Software| accessdate=August 13, 2023}} Former Harvard professor Michael E. Edelson introduced value averaging in his book ''Value Averaging'', published by Wiley in 1988.{{cite book| author=Michael E. Edelson| title= Value Averaging: The Safe and Easy Strategy for Higher Investment Returns| publisher=Wiley| date=2006| isbn=978-0-470-04977-8}} ==How value averaging works== The key idea is to create a ''Value Path'' which will describe the investment’s target level for each time period. You must simply make the proper investment or sale at each period so that the holdings are equal to the target value. The variables and the formula for the Value Path are as follows.{{cite web| url=http://www.sigmainvesting.com/advanced-investing-topics/value-averaging| title=Value Averaging| publisher=Sigma Investing| date=2007| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210508133532/http://www.sigmainvesting.com/advanced-investing-topics/value-averaging| archive-date=May 8, 2021}} Variables: *'''t''' = Time period (can be months, quarters, years, etc.) *'''Vt''' = Target value of investment at time period '''t''' *'''C''' = Target initial contribution per period *'''r''' = Expected rate of growth per period of investment *'''g''' = Expected rate of growth per period of contribution *'''R''' = Average rate of growth of investment and contribution To simplify the calculation, we will set '''R''' = ('''r''' + '''g''') / 2. Thus, '''R''' is just an average of the growth rates of the investment and the contribution amount. Now, the formula for the Value Path: :'''Vt''' = '''C''' * '''t''' * (1 + '''R''')'''t''' Now, you can simply use this formula to generate a Value Path for your investment. There are two different approaches for this depending on your needs. If you have a specific goal in mind, for example you need $100,000 in 10 years for your son’s college expenses, you can start with the final value of the Value Path and use that to determine the required value of your initial contribution ('''C'''). So, for our example, if we were working with monthly time periods, we would want '''V120''' = 100,000. Then, we solve '''V120''' = '''C''' * 120 * (1 + '''R''')'''120'''. On the other hand, if you have no specific savings goal but do know the amount of initial contribution that you are comfortable with, then you can plug in a value of '''C''' and solve for all the values of '''Vt'''. It is a good idea to use a spreadsheet to create your Value Paths and track your progress. An important thing to remember about the Value Path is that you should remain flexible and update your Value Path if circumstances change. For instance, if the rate of growth for your investment or your ability to contribute changes, you should re-calculate the Value Path from your current point. The Value Path formula depends heavily on your estimates of the rate of growth of the investment asset. Because of this, it is very important to provide as realistic rates as possible. ==Example== The following spreadsheet table compares value averaging with [[dollar cost averaging]]: {{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=1sqEPSLZUCSvNxVyO5D4Dg_gSAL56gfL7Jia4mBRxGmo |width=980 |height=580 }}
{{trim|{{Spreadsheet|key=1sqEPSLZUCSvNxVyO5D4Dg_gSAL56gfL7Jia4mBRxGmo}}}} ==Cautions and qualifications== *Value averaging adds a growth factor (by formula, consisting of estimates of both the investment's return as well as growth in the contribution level) to the regular periodic investment of savings flows. If your contribution amount is not expected to grow, you should set this factor at 0% so that investment growth is the only growth variable. *Value averaging may need both purchases and sales of the underlying investment, based on the investment performance of the investment. It requires a cash account for prospective purchases as well as any sales proceeds. *Value averaging sales can realize taxable capital gains. You might want to restrict it to tax advantaged accounts; or alternately, adopt a policy constraint forbidding or delaying sales in the taxable account. *You have to be careful in a declining market, as you will need to have additional funds available for investment. As time progresses and the account value grows, you may need even more funds to reach the amount required for the chosen period. If the market is volatile near the end of the investing time frame, you will need a lot of additional funds. This may catch investors unprepared for this additional savings requirement. *Value averaging most often provides a lower average cost per share than does DCA, and also provides for a higher internal rate of return (IRR). This does not, however, mean that value averaging will result in a higher realized profit.{{cite web| url=http://ssrn.com/abstract=1606347| author=Simon Hayley| title=Value Averaging and the Automated Bias of Performance Measures| date=March 11, 2011| accessdate=August 13, 2023}}. Available at SSRN. ==See also== *[[Dollar cost averaging]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.investopedia.com/articles/stocks/07/dcavsva.asp Choosing Between Dollar-Cost And Value Averaging], from Investopedia *[https://www.financialwisdomforum.org/gummy-stuff/DCA-vs-VA.htm DCA versus Value Averaging], gummy stuff *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131206124712/http://valueaveraging.ca/docs/Study_How_Value_Averaging_adds_Value.pdf How Value Averaging adds Value], Bruce Ramsey (November 15, 2010) *[http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470049774,descCd-DOWNLOAD.html Value Averaging], links to value averaging spreadsheets, from Wiley *{{Forum link| t=85583| title=Questions on Value Averaging| date=November 11, 2011}} ===Bibliography=== {| border="0" || * Marshall, Paul S., ''[http://www.financialdecisionsonline.org/archive/pdffiles/v13n1/marshall.pdf A Statistical Comparison Of Value Averaging vs. Dollar Cost Averaging and Random Investment Techniques]'', Journal of Financial and Strategic Decisions Volume 13, Number 1, Spring 2000. |} {{Portfolios}} [[Category:Portfolios]]

{{Notice| If you are considering hiring an investment adviser (financial adviser, broker, or investment firm) it is important that you '''check their background credentials''' and any complaints on file. The SEC and FINRA offer free tools to help with this, discussed [[#Background checks | below]]. }} '''Investment Advisers''' (IA)<ref group=note>U.S. financial law spelling uses ''adviser'', while elsewhere the spelling is ''advisor''.</ref> are people or firms who are paid to give advice on investing in securities such as stocks, bonds, [[mutual fund]]s, or [[exchange-traded fund]]s (ETFs). Depending on their classification, ''Investment Adviser'' are regulated. For example, an ''Investment Adviser'' who registers with the [http://www.sec.gov/ Securities and Exchange Commission] (SEC) must follow a fiduciary standard to act in their client's best interest. An adviser registered with the SEC is known as a ''Registered Investment Adviser'' (RIA).
== Investment advisers == Although many of the people who work at advisory firms fall under the definition of "investment adviser," the SEC generally does not require them to register individually as advisers with the SEC. Instead, the advisory ''firm'' itself must register with the SEC. The firm's registration covers its employees ''and'' other people under its control, provided they are working on the firm's behalf.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.sec.gov/about/offices/oia/oia_investman/rplaze-042006.pdf| title=The Regulation of Investment Advisers| publisher=SEC.gov| date=November 22, 2006| accessdate=August 31, 2023}}</ref> As a result, only firms can be ''Registered Investment Advisers'' (RIA), while its employees can only be ''Investment Adviser Representatives'' (IAR).<ref>{{forum link| p=1198928| title=A Firm is an RIA, Not a Person| date=October 6, 2011}}</ref>
''Registered Investment Advisers'' may not use the term “registered investment adviser” unless they are registered, nor can they use it to suggest a level of professional competence, education or special training. The term "RIA" should not appear after a person’s name, because using initials after a name usually indicates a degree or a licensed professional position requiring qualifications, and there are no federal qualifications for becoming an SEC-registered adviser.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.sec.gov/divisions/investment/advoverview.htm| title=Information for Newly-Registered Investment Advisers| publisher=SEC.gov| date=November 23, 2010| accessdate=August 31, 2023}}</ref> For example, someone could not use "RIA" on their business card.<ref>{{forum link| t=83550| title=A Firm is an RIA, Not a Person| date=October 3, 2011| author=[[Rick Ferri]]}}.</ref>
Investment advisers who manage less than $100 million in assets must register with the state securities agency in the state where they have their principal place of business.<ref name="RIA">{{cite web| url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Registered_investment_adviser| title=Registered investment adviser| publisher=Wikipedia| accessdate=August 31, 2023}}</ref>
Anyone registered with the FINRA typically makes commissions and fees from the products they sell (brokerage or mutual fund company). They must provide their clients with products that are "[[#Suitability|suitable]]" (the suitability standard), but not necessarily the cheapest or the best.<ref name="SECFin">{{forum link| p=1189157| title=Investment Advisor or do it ourselves| date=September 26, 2011}}.</ref>
==Regulations== Section 202(a)(11)(C) of the [[wikipedia:Investment Advisers Act of 1940|Investment Advisers Act of 1940]] exempts<ref name="RIA" /> from the definition of an ''Investment Adviser'' (and therefore the associated fiduciary standard){{blockquote|... any ''broker or dealer'' whose performance of such services is solely incidental to the conduct of his business as a broker or dealer and who receives no special compensation therefor.}}
In [https://www.sec.gov/file/release-nos-34-51523 Release 34-51523], the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) (the US Securities Self Regulatory Organization (SRO) with authority over ''Brokers and Dealers'') determined that Broker-Dealers are "not to be deemed investment advisers" and therefore are not required to follow the same fiduciary standards as ''Investment Advisers'' when recommending investments to clients (as are ''Registered Investment Advisers'' (RIA)).
Registered Representatives (RRs) affiliated with a [[wikipedia:Broker-dealer|Broker-dealer]] must therefore recommend securities that are deemed "[[#Suitability|suitable]]" for non-institutional clients.
===Suitability=== ''Suitability'' means that a broker can sell ''any'' fund or any investment as long as it fits the purpose. For example, if stocks are suitable for an investor, then it does not matter if a broker advises an 8% load stock fund that has 3% in annual fees because it is agreed that stocks in general are a suitable, and so any diversified stock mutual fund will do.<ref name="RF">{{forum link| p=1192950| title=Ameriprise employees sue firm for lousy 401k choices| date=September 30, 2011| author=[[Rick Ferri]]}}.</ref>
Suitability is entirely different from fiduciary standard. Under a fiduciary standard, an investment adviser must not only recommend suitable investments, but they must also recommend funds that are in the best interest of their client. Clearly, a fund with an 8% load and 3% in fees is not in the best interest of anyone. Low-cost index funds are in the best interest of clients.<ref name="RF" />
This is the difference between a broker's investment recommendations under a ''suitability'' standard, and an investment adviser's recommendations under a ''fiduciary'' standard.<ref name="RF" />
===Fiduciary standard=== On April 8, 2016, the Department of Labor issued revised regulations which widens the definition of a ''fiduciary'' for advisers who have control over retirement plans. This aims to avoid a conflict of interest between an adviser (including a broker-dealer) and the client. Firms must have complied with these new rules by July 1, 2019. Before July 1, 2019, advisers could ''intend'' to comply with these rules.<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/ebsa/ebsa20171127-0| title=U.S. Department of Labor Extends Transition Period For Fiduciary Rule Exemptions| publisher=US Department of Labor| accessdate=August 31, 2023}}</ref><ref group="note">Before July 1, 2019, the Department of Labor did not pursue claims against fiduciaries who worked diligently and in good faith to comply with the Fiduciary Rule.</ref>
==Background checks== If you are considering hiring an investment adviser (financial adviser, broker, or investment firm) it is important that you '''check their background credentials''' and any complaints on file. The SEC and FINRA offer free tools to help you do this.
It is a good idea for you to use both tools. If you cannot find a financial adviser in the SEC's Investment Adviser Public Disclosure (IARD) database, but you do find them in FINRA's Broker Check, you can consider this adviser to be a product salesperson.<ref name="SECFin" />
===SEC Investment Adviser Public Disclosure=== The SEC's Investment Adviser Public Disclosure (IAPD) database provides information about current and former Investment Adviser Representatives (IARs) and Investment Adviser firms registered with the SEC and/or state securities regulators.<ref name="IAS">[http://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?p=1188999#p1188999 Investment Advisor or do it ourselves], forum discussion, direct link to post.</ref> *[https://adviserinfo.sec.gov/ Investment Adviser Search], from the [http://www.sec.gov/ SEC] Choose either ''Individual'' or ''Firm'' to start. Be sure browser cookies are enabled. The results will contain links to "Investment Adviser Firm" or "Brokerage Firm" as applicable.
====Brokerage firm==== The Brokerage Firm link will launch into the FINRA's BrokerCheck ([[#FINRA BrokerCheck |below]]) which provides additional information such as a state-by-state breakdown where a broker is licensed to practice, or if any complaints have been filed.
====Investment adviser firm==== The "Investment Adviser Firm" link goes to Form ADV (Uniform Application for Investment Adviser Registration), each section appearing in a menu on the left-hand side. Among other items, you can use Form ADV to see if a firm offers [[Financial planning | financial planning]], as opposed to providing investment advice.<ref name="Kennedy">{{cite web| url=http://simplesmartinvesting.com/?p=175| title=How to select an investment adviser| date=March 10, 2013| author=Ian Kennedy| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313201150/http://simplesmartinvesting.com/?p=175| archive-date=March 13, 2016}}</ref>
Go to "Item 5 Information About Your Advisory Business" in the ADV form and look for:
*5F(1): Do you provide continuous and regular supervisory or management services to securities portfolios?
If the answer to 5F(1) is ''No'', this firm is not in the investment advisory business. It might give investment advice and sell investment products, but that does not make it an investment adviser that you want to manage your money.
Critically important is "Item 11 Disclosure Information." Every "No" box on this page should be checked, because a "Yes" indicates that the firm has violated some of the laws and regulations governing registered investment advisers.
Where a "Yes" is present, the firm must detail on form ADV the date and nature of the infraction, and how it was settled. A minor infraction, perhaps from some administrative error involving small amounts of money, may be forgiven, but you want to closely scrutinize any "Yes" on this page.<ref name="Kennedy" />
===FINRA BrokerCheck=== The [http://www.finra.org/index.htm Financial Industry Regulatory Authority], known as FINRA, is the largest non-governmental regulator for all securities firms doing business with the United States public—more than 5,000 firms employing more than 660,000 registered representatives. FINRA was created in 2007, consolidating NASD and NYSE Member Regulation.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.finra.org/AboutFINRA/| title=About the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority| publisher=FINRA| accessdate=August 31, 2023}}</ref>
FINRA BrokerCheck is a free tool to help investors check the professional background of current and former FINRA-registered securities firms and brokers. It should be the first resource you turn to when choosing whether to do business with a particular broker or brokerage firm. Note that financial advisers can also be registered brokers. *[https://brokercheck.finra.org/ BrokerCheck] Enable browser cookies. At the report summary, select "View Full PDF Report" (upper right corner) to get the full details. If applicable, the FINRA report will show any complaints filed against the adviser.
==Investment advisory fees== Some advisers may not charge for managing money market funds. If the exclude money market funds in the total portfolio value, you may be paying a different fee than you expect.<ref>{{Forum link| title=Wiki - Investment adviser - Advisory fees may not include money market funds| t=393371| author=LadyGeek| date=December 27, 2022}}.</ref>
Please check your adviser's service agreement for this exclusion.
=== Tax deductions === Before 2018, you could deduct fees paid to investment advisers for portfolio management ("investment counsel and advice") on your taxes, if the fees exceeded 2% of your adjusted gross income (AGI).<ref group="note">You used to categorize investment advisory fees, sometimes known as "wrap fees", as a miscellaneous itemized deduction. Miscellaneous itemized deductions have been removed from the tax code. See: [[Outline of tax law changes]].</ref>
After 2018, you can no longer deduct advisory fees.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/investment-expenses-whats-tax-deductible| title=Investment Expenses: What's Tax Deductible?| publisher=Charles Schwab| date=December 6, 2022| accessdate=August 31, 2023}}</ref>
